title: Bashlyk
text:
A bashlyk, also spelled bashlik (, , <a href="Abkhaz%20language">Abkhaz</a>: qtarpá, : , , <a href="Turkish%20language">Turkish</a>: Başlık; "baş" - head, "-lıq" ("Tatar") / "-lık" ("Turkish") - derivative suffix), is a traditional <a href="Turkic%20peoples">Turkic</a>, <a href="Caucasus">Caucasian</a>, <a href="Iranian%20peoples">Iranian</a>, and <a href="Cossack">Cossack</a> cone-shaped <a href="headdress">headdress</a> <a href="hood%20%28headgear%29">hood</a>, usually of leather, felt or wool, an ancient round topped felt <a href="Bonnet%20%28headgear%29">bonnet</a> with lappets for wrapping around the neck. Local versions determine the trim, which may consist of decorative cords, embroidery. metallized strings, fur balls or tassels. Among dozens of versions are winter bashlyks worn atop regular headdress, cotton bashlyks, homeknitted bashlyks, silk bashlyks, scarf bashlyks, down bashlyks, dress bashlyks, jumpsuit-type bashlyks, etc. Bashlyks are used as traditional folk garment, and as uniform headdress. 
A variation of bashlyks is a <a href="Kalpak">Kalpak</a> (Qalpaq), a cone-shaped headdress without lappets, mostly made of leather, felt or wool, as depicted in the Repin's painting below. "Kalpak" is also a component of the ethnic name "<a href="Kara-Kalpak">Kara-Kalpak</a>" (literally "a black kalpak" in <a href="Turkic%20languages">Turkic</a>), known from the history of the medieval <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a>, and from the modern <a href="Karakalpakstan">Karakalpak autonomous republic</a> in the western <a href="Syr%20Darya">Syr Darya</a> - <a href="Amu%20Darya">Amu Darya</a> interfluve in <a href="Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a>, north of the ancient <a href="Balkh">Balkh</a>. 
In modern times, bashlyks became fashionable in Russia in 1830-1840, after the <a href="Napoleonic%20War">Napoleonic War</a> with significant participation of the <a href="Bashkirs">Bashkir</a> cavalry. By the 1862 bashlyks were made a uniform headdress in <a href="Cossack">Cossack</a> armies, and later in other branches of Russian armed forces. The military bashlyk was bright yellow camel wool, with a yellow band. Officer bashlyks had gold or silver band. In <a href="Imperial%20Russian%20Army">Russian army</a> bashlyks lasted till 1917, when they became a trademark of <a href="White%20Army">White Army</a> uniform, and some White Army troops have the lappets tucked into the belt on the front instead of wrapping around the neck.
